title: Akin Defies Calls to Step Down in TV Interviews
content:
Visit NBCNews.com for breaking news , world news , and news about the economy
Representative Todd Akin on Wednesday morning took his case for staying in Missouri ’ s Senate race to the mainstream media he has blamed for his travails , telling both ABC ’ s “ Good Morning America ” and NBC ’ s “ Today ” show that his decision to defy his party ’ s leadership and conservative cognoscenti was a stand for the Republican voters of the Show Me State .
At the same time , he did not exclude on the possibility that he could still drop out .
“ The people of the state of Missouri elected me . This was a decision made by the people of Missouri , not by party bosses , ” he told “ Today ” ‘ s Matt Lauer .
Pressed about his staying power by “ Good Morning America ” ‘ s George Stephanopoulos , he conceded , “ I ’ m never going to say everything that can possibly happen . I don ’ t know the future . ”
Mr. Akin let an evening deadline pass for withdrawing from the race on Tuesday , defiantly telling conservative radio hosts he intended to ride grassroots conservative support to victory in his race to unseat Democratic Senator Claire McCaskill . He placed much of the blame for the firestorm on liberal media outlets , although the loudest calls for his departure were coming from top Republicans , including Mitt Romney , as well as conservative media voices such as Charles Krauthammer and Sean Hannity . The firestorm has diminished little since he said on Sunday that victims of “ legitimate ” rape rarely get pregnant because “ the female body has ways to try to shut that whole thing down . ”
In addition to the calls from prominent Republicans for him to step down , Mr. Akin has lost the financial and organizational backing of the National Republican Senatorial Committee and Crossroads GPS , a Republican advocacy group that had already spent more than $ 5 million to weaken Ms. McCaskill , announced Sunday that it was withdrawing from the state .
After spending days reaching out to conservative audiences through the radio shows of Mr. Hannity , Dana Loesch and Mike Huckabee , Wednesday ’ s efforts were aimed at a broader audience , including women . Earlier this week , he strongly apologized for suggesting some rapes were “ legitimate ” and others were not . On Wednesday , he focused on the notion , held broadly in ardent anti-abortion circles , that the trauma of rape somehow blocks conception .
“ I was misinformed , and I recognize that , ” he told Mr. Lauer .
Asked about the statement by Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus that he would not be welcome at next week ’ s Republican National Convention in Tampa , he said on ABC that he would “ honor their particular wishes . ”
But the Republican wish that he will exit a Senate campaign the GOP dearly wants to win is not likely to be honored any time soon .
“ This is not about me . It ’ s not about my ego . But it is about the voters of the state of Missouri , ” he said . “ They have chosen me . ”
